title: 103_hr4868
content: The Act may be cited as the "Railroad Unemployment Insurance Amendments Act of 1994". It includes a waiting period for unemployment benefits. Section 2(a)(1)(A) of the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to specify the payment of unemployment benefits. Benefits are payable to qualified employees for each day of unemployment exceeding 4 during a registration period within a period of continuing unemployment. Additionally, benefits are payable for each day of unemployment exceeding 7 during the employee's first registration period in a period of continuing unemployment, under certain conditions. During a period of continuing unemployment, if a qualified employee experiences days of unemployment due to a strike, no benefits will be paid for the first 14 days. Subsequent days of unemployment during the same strike will be eligible for benefits as per the usual conditions. During a period of continuing unemployment, the waiting period established in clause (ii) applies to the employee's first registration period in a new period of continuing unemployment based on the same stoppage of work. The term 'period of continuing unemployment' includes a single registration period with more than 4 days of unemployment or a series of consecutive registration periods, each with more than 4 days of unemployment. During a period of continuing unemployment, the waiting period applies to the employee's first registration period in a new period of continuing unemployment. The term includes a single registration period with more than 4 days of unemployment or a series of consecutive registration periods with more than 4 days of unemployment. No benefits shall be payable for any day of unemployment in a registration period where the total remuneration payable exceeds a certain amount. During a period of continuing unemployment, the waiting period applies to the employee's first registration period in a new period of continuing unemployment. No benefits shall be payable if the total remuneration payable exceeds a certain amount. SEC. 3. WAITING PERIOD FOR SICKNESS BENEFITS. Section 2(a)(1)(B) of the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to specify the payment of sickness benefits for qualified employees, including waiting periods and conditions for eligibility. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act specifies sickness benefits for qualified employees, with a waiting period that does not apply to the first registration period in a continuing sickness period. A period of continuing sickness is defined as consecutive days of sickness from one or more causes, or successive days of sickness due to a single cause with no interruption of more than 90 days. The period of continuing sickness ends when an employee exhausts sickness benefits. The period of continuing sickness ends when an employee exhausts sickness benefits under subsection (c) of this section. SEC. 4 amends the maximum daily benefit rate calculation under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act. The rate is based on the monthly compensation base multiplied by 5 percent and rounded down to the nearest dollar. SEC. 5 sets the maximum number of days for benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to set the maximum number of days for benefits at 130 for both unemployment and sickness within a benefit year. The total benefits paid to an employee cannot exceed their compensation in the base year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act limits benefits for sickness to 130 days within a benefit year, not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act limits benefits for sickness to 130 days within a benefit year, not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. Extended benefits are provided for employees with 10 or more years of service who exhaust their normal benefits for days of unemployment or sickness. Extended unemployment benefits or extended sickness benefits may be paid for up to 65 days within an extended benefit period. The benefit period begins on the first day of unemployment or sickness after exhausting normal benefits and lasts for 7 consecutive 14-day periods. Extended unemployment benefits or extended sickness benefits may be paid for up to 65 days within an extended benefit period, starting from the first day of unemployment or sickness after exhausting normal benefits. The extended benefit period shall not extend beyond the beginning of the first registration period in a benefit year when the employee qualifies for benefits again. Additionally, the extended benefit period for sickness benefits terminates the day before the employee turns 65, unless it is needed to pay benefits for days of unemployment. Accelerated benefits may also be available for employees. With 10 or more years of service, an employee who did not voluntarily retire or leave work without good cause, and has 14 or more consecutive days of unemployment or sickness, will begin the succeeding general benefit year on the first day of the month. The succeeding benefit year for an employee with 10 or more years of service begins on the first day of the month in which unemployment or sickness starts. There is an exception for sickness benefits after age 65, and the Board may use available records to determine age. Repeal of Deadwood Provision in the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act and repeal of expired provision related to supplemental unemployment benefits. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
